text: all right welcome everybody we're gonna get started a little bit early just a couple of administrative notes before we
get started first if you could just silence your phones out of respect for the speakers this session is also being
recorded so you don't want your awesome ring tone to show up in the video fire exits are out into the right restrooms
out to the left and then at the end of the session there will be a survey and the app if you guys can please please
fill it out they'd be great without further ado your first speaker Kumar hi
everyone my name is Kumar Venkateswara I'm a principal product manager in the AWS machine learning team and the
product that I primarily focus on is called Amazon sage maker which is a machine learning platform product
intended to accelerate your machine learning lifecycle so I like to usually
start out with a little bit of context as to why machine learning is important because sometimes you think about the
heavy lift that's involved in getting machine learning and setting up an infrastructure for machine learning and
you think why is it really important for us to do use machine learning are there alternative technologies that we can use
in order to accomplish the same kinds of things that we would be able to to do
with machine learning and if you look at the numbers around data machine learning
is centered primarily around data and the growth in data that we've seen over
the last decade or so we've seen a thousand percent growth in data every
two years as in ninety percent of all data has been produced in the last two years and if you compare that to the
population growth of 1.5 percent per year roughly or 1.5 percent in the last
two years even it's not nearly enough to keep pace with the level of data growth
which means that the only way to be able to use this data effectively you can't
hire additional people in order to work with data you have to be able to apply some
technology in order to adequately use that data so the result has been that
most of this data has been untapped and there's no way for us to grow our workforce fast enough to keep up with
this data growth so machine learning the way I see it is the solution to this
problem in a way it's the technology that enables you to take human expertise
distill it learn it in a scalable way and apply it so that you can actually
get something useful out of this enormous volume of data so the first
thing I like to think about is what do I need to do in order to be successful with machine learning you have to start
out with the right question and sometimes there's a bit there are subtleties with the kinds of questions
that you ask with machine learning you you think I've actually had some c-level
officers come to me and and say I'd like machine learning to be a solution for
how I can lead my business and well that's nice it's not a precise enough
question that we would be able to answer it with machine learning collect the data that we need figure out the right
algorithm and figure out how to apply that knowledge it has to be something much more scoped and precise so not how
will the weather be tomorrow it's more what will the high temperature be tomorrow in a very scoped kind of way
you also want to be able to say ask additional questions that help you get
to that so you can get guidance on how to run your business or how to run your agency or organization through that but
at the same time you have to figure out the right set of questions that you need to ask in order to get that answer the
kinds of questions will it rain tomorrow will it rain tomorrow was it unusually hot what is the chance
it'll rain these types of questions are the kinds of questions where you can take data you can collect data you can
use that historical data in order to develop a model and then make predictions about
the way things were and if you look at these questions you have to make sure that you're actually asking the right
question if the question is what should I wear tomorrow and you're asking what
will the weather be well you're going to be in here so if you're gonna be in here what does it matter you need to know
what the temperature is in here not the temperature outside so you have to make sure that as you're preparing to do this
that you're asking the right questions in order to make it actionable for the thing that you really want to know not
just that but you want the right data and the right compute so that you can apply machine learning to that problem
and an example that that I've heard a lot of over the past few days is the
example of object recognition in imagenet it's it's pretty a pretty
common example it's something that has data that's very easily available there's a lot of research in the area
and it's widely usable in a lot of different situations on the other hand
if you say I'm gonna develop a model and object detection model with imagenet and then I'm going to apply it to overhead
images that doesn't work you're not able to use that same kind of thing because it wasn't trained with overhead data one
of the customers that I've talked to actually has the opposite problem which is they have a robotic cleaning device
that runs on the floor and the view that that robotic cleaning device has of the
world is from the bottom up which means that it also can't use the image net
data set you also can't train that with the image net data set because a chair doesn't look the same when you're
looking at it from two inches off the ground so it's important to have the right data for that question that you're
trying to answer the other thing it's important to have is the right compute
so for the large volumes of data that you would have in in the these image
cases you probably want a GPU and you want to be able to apply a large number
of GPUs to these problems depending on this as of your data sets certainly if you're doing if you're learning on a big data
set like image matter space net you want a very very large body of compute to be
able to apply to it on the other hand if you're doing something like gradient boosted trees using XG boost or
something like that you would want very powerful CPUs and looking at tabular
data and XG boost you'd want CPUs like Intel CPUs in order to apply to that the
other thing that you want to make sure that you're able to do is you want to have lots of iteration on on through
this entire process it's not a single-shot process it's something that takes a considerable amount of iteration
and it takes experimentation to get correct so one of the challenges with
that is is not only computational in technology related but the challenge
with that is if you have a situation where your organization expects the results to be perfect the first time out
that's usually not going to be the case with machine learning you want to be able to have the freedom to iterate on
it deploy things in a way that is controlled be able to learn from the things that are deployed collect data
that helps you inform your next iteration better and so on and so on the the value of applying machine learning
to to these problems is not just that you're able to get good results
initially but it's the fact that you can continue to collect data and can continue to get better and better over
time and if it's the fact that you get better over time that's the real value
in machine learning in other words moving fast and steadily is the thing
that wins so just like software development is iterative you want to be able to lean forward and push things out
and to be able to understand what's going on and then iterate and iterate and iterate until you get it to the
point where it's a great experience you want to do the same thing with machine learning it also because it feeds on
data you want to be able to push it out understand what data that you need to collect and then go
back and iterate on that and make sure that you're able to take advantage of the data that you're collecting so
what's the result of that the result of that is that you want to make sure that
you're making decisions in such a way that they're flexible enough that you're able to iterate and you're not deciding
on every iteration hey for this iteration I want tensorflow therefore I want this infrastructure and
I have to build this infrastructure around it and pay for this other iteration I need PI torch and I need to
build this other iteration or this other infrastructure around it the important
thing is to distill out the things that are common between the iterations and
between the the variations that you're likely to have between experiments and between projects and that way you can
focus on the things that are unique to a particular iteration or a particular project because that's where you want to
focus your efforts and that's how you get quicker at iterating so how can
Amazon sage maker help you with this process our goal at AWS is to put
machine learning in the hands of every developer and part of the reason for that is because of this iterative
process you also for this iterative process you need to be able to have as many people who are able to do machine
learning as possible you want to conserve those expert data science resources those expert machine learning
engineers for the truly hard problems that are intractable except by a machine learning engineer and you want to enable
all of your developers to be as productive as possible using machine learning that's one of the the
challenges with machine learning is that you want to be able to democratize it as much as possible in order to move faster
so what was the thing when as we as we step back and we looked at that problem
one of the things that we decided in AWS is we need to build an infrastructure that allows data scientists to be data
scientists focus on the data science and machine learning parts of the problem and not worry about the
infrastructure while at the same time we wanted to be able to enable developers
to take advantage of some of these data science technologies in a way that they would be able to understand and they
would be able to utilize them for some of the problems that the data scientists wouldn't necessarily be able to get to
quickly and the third thing is be able to transition between one audience to the other so if a developer takes a shot
at a problem says you know I'm gonna look at this fraud detection type of
problem I'm gonna try and find this particular type of fraud and I'm gonna develop a model around it maybe I'll use
XG boost because it's convenient and I know how to use it and I have this tabular data set I'm gonna apply it and
try and figure it out and suppose they come up with a result that doesn't mean business goals then you need to be able
to say okay fine we'll take that project and then transfer it over to a data scientist and they would be able to use
those previous iterations in order to be able to take it over the finish line and complete the mission what we found was
that machine learning was too complicated for everyday developers it was there's so many barriers through the
entire process it's everything from collecting training data from everywhere and we actually one of the things that
we did in Sage Maker in order to make this process easier was we developed a
way that you could do active learning so you could label the data and have automated labeling of that data and the
machine learning model would learn how to label that data as it went along and the reason we did that is because it's
very challenging to collect and prepare training data for machine learning the
second thing we did was we looked at choosing and optimizing machine learning
it's that's one of the the challenges that we we saw that people were having in the space developers would come in
and they wouldn't know necessarily which algorithm to use and how to decide between them it was difficult for both
data scientists and developers particularly in spaces that needed high security
to create these environments in which to build and train these models because of
the security requirements we we saw customers were ending up in this situation where every project needed to
be approved by security which doesn't lend itself to that easy quick iteration
that I had talked about earlier and then of course once you get to training and tuning it's not only difficult to do or
to develop distributed training algorithms that you would need for this large volume of data but it's also
difficult to use things like Bayesian hyper parameter optimization which
enable you to tune that model to meet your your objectives and that's
something that you can throw compute at the problem and you can do things like grid search but it ends up being
expensive and hard and something that you wouldn't be able to do on a regular basis and then of course the last part
is once you have this model you want to be able to take it and deploy it into production wherever you want it to be in
order to get business value out of it because at the end of it that's where you get the business value once the
model is deployed and once it's in production and once it's actually doing things in that production environment
and in that production environment you want to be able to monitor and manage it and you want to see which version is
deployed and you want to be able to deploy multiple versions and do blue/green deployments in order to make
sure that your infrastructure still remains up in spite of the fact that you're pushing new versions every so
often you want to be able to say you know this model is meeting our latency goals this model or this solution has
been up and maintains our availability goes and so on there are a lot of operational challenges and when you get
to the right side of this flow you get into a realm where data scientists didn't feel very comfortable either so
not only was it too complicated for everyday developers it was too complicated for every day day of
scientists as well and they didn't feel like they had enough ownership of the end solution which meant that overall
this was taking customers six to 18 months per iteration which is just way way too long so what did we do we said
let's break that down and let's break it down into manageable pieces and let's develop capabilities that we can offer
to our customers around each of these things so we started out with this notion of there's a build environment in
which you're able to explore the data understand what the data is and to be able to plan out the machine learning
process then we said there's a training environment in which you can take that
data perform distributed training and to be able to understand that one of the challenges that we had in the
distributed training space is that everyone has their own favorite algorithm and everyone has expertise in
an area this is this is one of the the things that we realized pretty early on
is that Amazon is great at machine learning it's something that we've been doing for decades but every time I talk
to a customer every time I come to a conference like this I learn new things I learn more about how people do machine
learning so we couldn't say hey you know what I have the solution for you we
can't do that because there are experts in this audience that know more about
their particular to Amane way more than I do which means that we needed a way that we had this training environment
that we could take your expertise and to be able to plug it into the sage maker infrastructure in order to make it so
that you can take the things that are unique to a particular project and only focus on those and then lastly we have
we had to create this integrated deployment environment with managed inference clusters in order to
accommodate both batch and real-time applications so in this particular space
I think there are particular aspects of this that are of higher value than maybe in some other spaces and I thought I
would take a little bit of time to talk about those particular aspects of things the first one is the set of security
features a lot of this audience has unique security requirements I know you
guys treat security very very seriously the risk of data leakage or anything like that is
very high and you're very concerned about it so one of the things that we
did was we said sage maker will be security first we will make sure that
the environment that data is handled in is up to the standards of the highest
security that we can think of that we can get feedback from customers on and we will make sure it adheres to those
specifications so we looked at things like virtual private clouds which AWS
offers and integrated with that we looked at private link which allows you to train and deploy models without any
of the data going over the Internet at all of course there are things like
encryption at rest encryption at transit were of course also looking at things
like homomorphic encryption and differential privacy in this environment in order to keep pushing the security
boundary and the goal here is provide an environment that allows customers to
take this environment and use it for all of their data not just the unclasp data
or the lowest security level type of data we want it to be suitable for use
with all of the data that you have so what kind of thing does this look like I'm putting code up here we don't
necessarily need to go deeply into the code but the idea here is that you would
be able to within this environment provide specific parameters that allow
you to say it should be in this particular subnet it should be encrypted it should be very easy to incorporate in
the security features for any particular project that needs it the second thing
we did was we said it has to be modular everyone has their own solution that they like we even had had customers in
the commercial space talk about how they loved their SPARC environment they just want in some way to deploy it so what we
said was we really want to make it so that it's modular so that you can use
what you need and supplement your overall machine learning floo so that you go faster through the
entire process because again that's the goal faster iteration so you can
supplement what you have and what you like with the things that you don't have in order to make it possible to go
through this entire flow really quickly and the result of that is that all of
these components are addressable through api's when it comes to creating the notebook environment that you use in
order to analyze the data you have a single API called that produces back a
URL that you can use and you can use that pre signed URL in any portal that
you have it can basically integrate together with your application in a way that end-users don't even know that
behind it is sage maker and the same is true with both training and deployment
whether it's real time deployment or batch deployment all of the components that we have in Sage Maker
are driven by these api's the next thing
that's interesting is that because we designed this in a module in modular
fashion we also had a way that we could produce things like optimizing and
deploying the hardware so we ended up having customers like GE Healthcare who are very interested in using sage maker
for their their critical data they had critical healthcare data they had x-ray
images MRI images and so on and they wanted to be able to use machine learning for those problems for similar
reasons that I described with the deluge of data because you can have so much
data coming in but at the end of the day you can't have radiologists look at all of it sometimes you end up with an
intern that's been on call for 36 hours straight and can barely keep their eyes open as they're looking at the x-ray so
what do we want to be able to do we want to be able to take that model put it
onto an x-ray machine have the x-ray machine highlight areas of interest or provide ways that you can aid that poor
intern and that means that that can't be necessarily in Sage maker
it has to be something that can be deployed to an x-ray machine because not all those x-ray machines are connected
to the cloud sometimes some of you have told me about situations where you have
things in the field and you have devices in the field that you have to deploy to so I wanted to make sure that we were
designing sage maker in a way that was compatible with that so you could train in the cloud train and sage maker and
deploy to the device so that your inferences are close to where your data is so what does that look like you can
create this compilation job that optimizes it optimizes for a particular hardware target in this particular case
it's a Raspberry Pi you can optimize it for that Raspberry Pi take those model
files and you can deploy it and that's true of everything that we train with in Sage Maker you can take those you can
take that data file those data files live in your account and then you can take that and deploy to whatever target
you want whether it's sage maker or not sage maker the next thing that we did
was we wanted to make sure that we provided an array of choices so for
developers they don't know how to choose algorithms and having them develop these

those examples and we'll also develop the algorithms the most common algorithms that people use in this space
and we'll develop those so we have a choice of 18 different built-in
algorithms within sage maker but for the experts we also support open source various open source frameworks including
tensorflow pi torch MX net chain or extra boost scikit-learn and we continue to add to
that as we get feedback from customers so not only can you use the built-in algorithms in cases where they're

on and so on which means that you have the flexibility to be able to use this for all of your applications so next I'd
